Linear Algebra Chapter 1 Vector Spaces 1.1 Vector Space

Linear Algebra Deepak Bastola 2024-05-18 Chapter 1 Vector Spaces 1.1 Vector Space A vector space \(V\) over a field \(F\) is a set equipped with two operations: Vector Addition: An operation \(+ : V \times V \to V\) that assigns to each pair of vectors \(\alpha, \beta \in V\) a vector \(\alpha + \beta \in V\). Scalar Multiplication: An operation \(\cdot : F \times V \to V\) that assigns to each scalar \(a \in F\) and each vector \(\alpha \in V\) a vector \(a \cdot \alpha \in V\). These operations must satisfy the following axioms for all vectors \(\alpha, \beta, \gamma \in V\) and all scalars \(a, b \in F\): Vector Addition Commutativity of Addition: \(\alpha + \beta = \beta + \alpha\) Associativity of Addition: \((\alpha + \beta) + \gamma = \alpha + (\beta + \gamma)\) Identity Element of Addition (Law of Zero): There exists a unique element \(\mathbf{0} \in V\) such that \(\alpha + \mathbf{0} = \alpha\) for all \(\alpha \in V\). Inverse Elements of Addition: For every \(\alpha \in V\), there exists a unique element \(-\alpha \in V\) such that \(\alpha + (-\alpha) = \mathbf{0}\). Scalar Multiplication Assosiativity of Scalar Multiplication: \(a \cdot (b \cdot \alpha) = (a b) \cdot \alpha\) Identity Element of Scalar Multiplication (Law of One): \(1 \cdot \alpha = \alpha\) for all \(\alpha \in V\), where \(1\) is the multiplicative identity in \(F\). Distributivity Distributivity of Scalar Multiplication with Respect to Vector Addition: \(a \cdot (\alpha + \beta) = a \cdot \alpha + a \cdot \beta\) Distributivity of Scalar Multiplication with Respect to Field Addition: \((a + b) \cdot \alpha = a \cdot \alpha + b \cdot \alpha\) Examples 1. The n-tuple space, \(\mathbb{F^n}\). In fact, \(\mathbb{F}^n\) is the set of all ordered \(n\)-tuples of elements of \(\mathbb{F}\), i.e., \[ \mathbb{F}^n = \{(x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n) \mid x_i \in \mathbb{F} \text{ for all } i = 1, 2, \ldots, n \}. \] Since if \(\mathbf{u} = (u_1, u_2, \ldots, u_n)\), \(\mathbf{v} = (v_1, v_2, \ldots, v_n) \in \mathbb{F}^n\) and \(a \in \mathbb{F}\), then \[ \mathbf{u} + \mathbf{v} = (u_1 + v_1, u_2 + v_2, \ldots, u_n + v_n) \in \mathbb{F}^n\] because each \(u_i + v_i \in \mathbb{F}\) and \[ a\mathbf{v} = (a v_1, a v_2, \ldots, a v_n) \in \mathbb{F}^n \] because each \(a v_i \in \mathbb{F}\). For all vectors \(\mathbf{u}, \mathbf{v}, \mathbf{w} \in \mathbb{F}^n\) and for all scalars \(a, b \in \mathbb{F}.\) Vector Addition Commutativity of addition: \[ \mathbf{u} + \mathbf{v} = (u_1 + v_1, u_2 + v_2, \ldots, u_n + v_n) = (v_1 + u_1, v_2 + u_2, \ldots, v_n + u_n) = \mathbf{v} + \mathbf{u}\] Associativity of addition: \[\begin{align*} (\mathbf{u} + \mathbf{v}) + \mathbf{w} &= (u_1 + v_1, u_2 + v_2, \ldots, u_n + v_n) + \mathbf{w} \\&= ((u_1 + v_1) + w_1, (u_2 + v_2) + w_2, \ldots, (u_n + v_n) + w_n) \\&= (u_1 + (v_1 + w_1), u_2 + (v_2 + w_2), \ldots, u_n + (v_n + w_n))\\&= \mathbf{u} + (v_1 + w_1, v_2 + w_2, \ldots, v_n + w_n) \\&=\mathbf{u} + (\mathbf{v} + \mathbf{w}) \end{align*}\] Since addition in \(\mathbb{F}\) is associative, \((u_i + v_i) + w_i = u_i + (v_i + w_i)\) for all \(i\). Identity Element of Addition : The zero vector \(\mathbf{0} = (0, 0, \ldots, 0) \in \mathbb{F}^n\) acts as the additive identity because \[ \mathbf{v} + \mathbf{0} = (v_1 + 0, v_2 + 0, \ldots, v_n + 0) = (v_1, v_2, \ldots, v_n) = \mathbf{v} \] Inverse Elements of Addition: For each \(\mathbf{v} = (v_1, v_2, \ldots, v_n) \in \mathbb{F}^n\), there exists \(-\mathbf{v} = (-v_1, -v_2, \ldots, -v_n) \in \mathbb{F}^n\) such that \[ \mathbf{v} + (-\mathbf{v}) = (v_1 + (-v_1), v_2 + (-v_2), \ldots, v_n + (-v_n)) = (0, 0, \ldots, 0) = \mathbf{0}\] \end{enumerate} Scalar Multiplication Associativity of scalar multiplication: \[\begin{align*} a(b \mathbf{v}) &= a(b v_1, b v_2, \ldots, b v_n) = (a(b v_1), a(b v_2), \ldots, a(b v_n)) \\&= ((ab) v_1, (ab) v_2, \ldots, (ab) v_n) = (ab) \mathbf{v} \end{align*}\] Identity Element of Scalar Multiplication: \[ 1 \mathbf{v} = 1(v_1, v_2, \ldots, v_n) = (1 v_1, 1 v_2, \ldots, 1 v_n) = (v_1, v_2, \ldots, v_n) = \mathbf{v}\] Distributivity Distributivity of scalar multiplication with respect to vector addition \[\begin{align*} a(\mathbf{u} + \mathbf{v}) &= a(u_1 + v_1, u_2 + v_2, \ldots, u_n + v_n) \\&= (a(u_1 + v_1), a(u_2 + v_2), \ldots, a(u_n + v_n)) \\&= (a u_1 + a v_1, a u_2 + a v_2, \ldots, a u_n + a v_n) \\&= a \mathbf{u} + a \mathbf{v} \end{align*}\] Distributivity of scalar multiplication with respect to field addition \[\begin{align*} (a + b)\mathbf{v} &= (a + b)(v_1, v_2, \ldots, v_n) = ((a + b)v_1, (a + b)v_2, \ldots, (a + b)v_n) \\&= (a v_1 + b v_1, a v_2 + b v_2, \ldots, a v_n + b v_n) \\&= a \mathbf{v} + b \mathbf{v} \end{align*}\] Thus, \(\mathbb{F}^n\) satisfies all these axioms, it is a vector space.
